utterances.sentences: This is Bailey. Make him famous.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I like the pocket square. That's sharp. Can I give you a little secret? Dress for the job you want, not for the job you have.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I've got to take a plate back.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: You're just doing it for the camera. We know.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Are you eating that?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I'm actually working. This is not my place. I just sat down.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: You worked the whole night.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: We've got Jesse Watters and Dana Perino. I mean, obviously --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Jesse, that made us look like we were the only celebrities there.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I know. There was a lot bigger celebrities.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Much bigger celebrities. It was a really amazing --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You're a good waitress. You had plates going up your arm.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes, that's how I got through college.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: And she was a DJ. She's recession proof.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I mean, I worked a lot. But it was a really wonderful event. What did you think about meeting Kevin Carter?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: He was great. And that young man who I give a tip about the pocket square, he was the ambassador. He's a young kid. And we raised a lot of money for the Make-a-Wish Foundation, so it was worthwhile. Maybe Kimberly can come next year and wait some tables, as well. Juan, I'm not so sure. Greg is probably busy.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: I'm very good at dishes, too.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Oh, but you know what they have? They needed bartenders.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I would be a great bartender.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Chris Collinsworth bartended the entire thing. I think that was his way of getting out of waiting tables.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Also, Tito Ortiz was there. And that was a big deal, right?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: He gave me a tip on how to fight. He said, "If you're ever in a fight, Watters, punch them in the nose."

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: He's right.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Because it stuns them and then their eyes water, and they'll blink.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Because like, he can punch. And you could...

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I can take a punch. I've got a big chain.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I've never been to an event like that before where you have all sorts of different people. And the patrons, they pay to come to the dinner, but then they have to pay extra for all sorts of other things. And then there's the live auction.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's right. And someone won a tour of FOX News, and they're going to watch "The Five" show, as well.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Cool.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: What did they pay for that?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I'm not going to tell.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I know. Do you know?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I know, but I think you took a cut of that, didn't you, Dana?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: No, I didn't take a cut. Oh, my gosh. But it was a lot. And of course, it's going to be worth it. All right. Thanks for inviting us. "One More Thing" is up next.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: "One More Thing." Well, you probably didn't know this, but I'm quite the entrepreneur. I spend my weekends trying to invent new products. And I think I came across something that I think is going to be very big.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Let's see.

utterances.speaker: KAT TIMPF, FOX NEWS
utterances.sentences: Sometimes I need the hard news of the day. But other times I just want to cuddle. Why can't I have both?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Well, now you can with the new Bret Bear. He's fair and balanced and unafraid to snuggle. Just squeeze his tummy and get informed.

utterances.speaker: BRET BAIER, FOX NEWS ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: The 41st president wants to go to Maine this summer.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Bret Bear fits in with even the most sophisticated crowd.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.sentences: Jeff Sessions will not recuse himself from the investigation into the president's personal attorney, Michael Cohen.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: So get your Bret Bear today.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.sentences: I'm Bret Baier in Washington, and I'll see you later.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Oh, yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Shark Tank.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: People might actually want that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That's the protype.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I like it.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: I like it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: All right. Tomorrow, I have -- sometimes I have just perfect timing with all this foreign policy stuff going on. I have Condoleezza Rice on the show tomorrow, the 2 p.m. show, "The Daily Briefing." She just wrote a book called "Political Risk." She wrote it with Hoover senior fellow Amy Zegart. And we're going to be able to talk about North Korea, Iran and what else, you guys? Any other hot spots you want to talk about, China?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Yes. I want to talk about Syria.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Vermont.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: And Vermont.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Central America.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I hope you tune in tomorrow.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: We love Condoleezza.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, you should also ask her about college basketball. She's the head of the college basketball.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And knows a lot about that.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: She can come on The Five.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: That's true.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: She canceled us.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: I know.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: All right. Big hockey night in Nashville. I am not talking about the Predators playing Winnipeg in the Western Conference finals. It was a big night, because the National Hockey League team honored James Shaw Jr. About a week ago, the 29-year-old heroically tackled a gunman who had already killed four people and wounded four others at a local all- night restaurant. Shaw got to meet the team's coach. He was given his own personalized jersey. And when he was announced to the huge crowd, they gave him a roaring ovation. Shaw has also raised more than $160,000 for the victims of the Waffle House shooting. Way to go and Predators, you guys go, too. That was a really class act.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Amazing. All right, Kimberly.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: And at that same hockey game, Carrie Underwood, America's sweetheart besides Dana Perino, she took the ice at the Bridgestone Arena at Nashville over the weekend, and she performed an absolutely flawless rendition of the national anthem. If you would, take a listen. CARRIE UNDERWOOD, COUNTRY MUSIC STAR (singing): O say can you see by the dawn's early light?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: How beautiful was that? Now that is how you sing a national anthem. She nailed it and she did it in front of her husband, Mike Fisher, who is the team's central player. And his face say -- I think she was like his good luck charm, because they --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: They won.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Had a 5-4 win, exactly. The Predators against the Jets.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Fergie should pay attention. That's how you do it. So there was a paddle boarder in Australia, and something ridiculous happened. I think he's paddling along. Oh! Taken out by a dolphin. It looks like the dolphin did it on porpoise. Did it on porpoise, Greg.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Oh, that poor dolphin.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Body-checks this guy.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That's amazing.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: It's one of my biggest fears. It's why I don't go out.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: They're violent animals.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Well, you don't paddle board.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: They're violent animals.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Don't go whale watching.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Dolphins can attack you in other ways, too.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Set your DVR. Never miss an episode of "The Five." "Special Report" up next. Hey, Bret, how are you doing?

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.sentences: You know, I didn't buy into that when you told me what you are doing.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Isn't it cute?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It's waiting here for you.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.sentences: Fair, balanced and ready to snuggle.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Squeeze it.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Look at his ears, are so cute. Little fuzzy.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.sentences: Thank you. So cute. Content and Programming Copyright 2018 Fox News Network, LLC. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED. Copyright 2018 CQ-Roll Call, Inc. utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Hi, I'm Greg Gutfeld with Kimberly Guilfoyle, Juan Williams, Jesse Watters, and she wind surf with a post-it note, Dana Perino -- "The Five."

utterances.speaker: Hooray. Saturday was the White House Correspondents' Dinner. Here's a clip
UNINDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: It's a trash fire.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: We could stop there. Now, everything went as planned. The comedian, an undiluted leftist plucked from "The Daily Show" assembly line of press approved progs unloaded on the White House. But like a tortoise on crutches, you could see the jokes limping toward you.

utterances.speaker: The dinner is now just old news, an orgy of self-congratulations, selfies, and predictable barbs masked as edgy, like the Sarah Sanders stuff
MICHELLE WOLF, COMEDIAN
utterances.utterance: I have to say, I'm a little star struck. I love you as Aunt Lydia in "The Handmaid's Tale." I actually really like Sarah. I think she's very resourceful. Like she burns facts and then she uses that ash to create a perfect smoky eye. Like, maybe she's born with it. Maybe it's lies. Probably lies. And I'm never really sure what to call Sarah Huckabee Sanders, you know. Is it Sarah Sanders? Is it Sarah Huckabee Sanders? Like, what's Uncle Tom, but for white women who disappoint other white women?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Now, Wolf reminds us that you can smear women as long as you on the right side politically. The media calls that a roast. If you did it, it would be called misogyny. But progs play by different rules. Take Joy Reid, whatever she wrote will be excused by people who would crucify you for much, much less. Being on the left excuses everything, you can drive girls into the drink or run the Klan and still sit in the senate as long as you're a Democrat. Now, the comic's defenders will say, but Trump said bad things about women too. You're right. He said bad things about everyone. But if he wasn't president and Marco Rubio was, do you think Michelle would be any nicer to Rubio? He's pro-life. She's this:

utterances.speaker: WOLF
utterances.utterance: Mike Pence is also very anti-choice. He thinks abortion is murder, which, first of all, don't knock it until you try it. And when you do try it really knock it. You know, you've got to get that baby out of there.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Maybe that's what Brian Stelter considers brave material. Take that unborn baby. So, yeah, Trump had said bad things, but he crushed ISIS and might just solve a 60-year-old problem called North Korea. I'll take the trade-off even if I must listen to really bad jokes once a year. So should you. Kimberly, I go to you because I believe you feel strongly about this topic. Am I correct?

utterances.speaker: KIMBERLY GUILFOYLE, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Yes, because you are monitoring me all weekend and this week.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: You're correct.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, I was outside your house.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: All right. So, I have to tell you, I felt that this was so mean-spirited that it wasn't anything that was like comedic about. There was nothing to be gained for her saying these types of things that were directly targeted at Sarah Sanders. I think the majority of what she had to say went against her. This isn't advancing women. This isn't even advancing the first amendment. This is just proffering cruelty. And I think if you were sitting in a chair like that to listen to that, and everybody, basically, some people, I guess, laughed, etcetera. But to allow her to even to continue to go on in this way, I thought it was absolutely terrible. I admit, we were all invited, we didn't go. Well, you went. I think you're the only one of the five of us, right? OK. And -- so, Juan will say with his, you know, personal experience was being there and actually listening in the room. Sometimes it's a little different. But at home, and I re-watched it so many times and I felt so sad for her. It's just one of those things that Sarah conducted herself, you know, beautifully and really handled herself well. To sit there and listen to these things, so mean-spirited, bullying, that's what it is. I wouldn't like it if she said that about, you know, a man, a woman, a child. But to do that, what did Sarah Sanders ever do to hurt to deserve those kinds of personal attacks on that level of vitriol? I mean, she should feel horrible about herself when she goes to bed and she wakes up in the morning, Michelle Wolf, because none of that was funny whatsoever.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: OK. Dana, they would probably respond that, A, Sarah -- because Trump wasn't there, Sarah.

utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Becomes the target. GUTFELD: She becomes the target. She's the proxy. And number two, Trump has said things about, you know, people's faces twice, so it's like.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And some people laughed, right?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah, yeah.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Across the board, I don't think it's good or funny. The interesting thing about this is that -- just two months ago or three months ago, the president went to the Gridiron Dinner, and he -- it was one first of these that he's attended. He brought the house down. He's very funny. His speech was great. Nancy Pelosi was one of the speakers. I think that was her that night, and then Tom Cotton. Usually, if you have an elected leader who has -- it's not easy to give a speech like that. They have to practice, and it costs actually a lot because you usually farm it out to some great speechwriter.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And I don't think Washington, D.C. needs to bring in anyone from the outside to do these types of things. The Gridiron Dinner has never done it. It's always fantastic. The line that they have is, the Gridiron singes, but it never burns. I do hope that's the last of the sound bites that I have to hear because her voice is really -- it gets to me. Craig Ferguson was one of the only comedians there that I thought was so gentle because he basically just made fun of himself the entire time, and he complemented me, so that was like -- I remember that. The other thing is when she talks about the abortion joke.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You know, one thing you could say in response is that -- well, at least she called it a baby.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah, I think that was the biggest flaw.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Oh, so now you think it's a baby.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Good, because we're going to take that to the congress.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah. I think that was a big flaw on her, and it undermined her joke. Also, to your point, you know, Obama gives great speeches. They didn't need a comedian.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Usually, the elected leaders who give funny speeches are usually - - actually, not even elected leaders. Laura Bush, when she did it the one year at the White House correspondents' dinner, was hilarious when she called herself a Desperate Housewives. I mean, everybody got it. And you don't need to bring in somebody from the outside of D.C.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah. Jesse?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I agree with you, Dana, it should be no more, unless president -- like when President Obama spoke, he was very funny, he was very entertaining. Guess what? People would actually go then. No one wants to sit there and listen to this nonsense.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah. Jesse, not a rousing success.

utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: No. Roseanne Barr said the first rule of comedy, you don't target someone in the audience who's more famous than you are. You'll lose the entire crowd. And this is what happens. You book a C-list comedian to make fun of the D.C. A-listers. Look who they've had the last couple of years, Cecily Strong, Larry Wilmore, Hasan Minhaj, Michelle Wolf, I've never even heard of any of these people.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They're all Daily Show.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah, I agree.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: But this is who the left is. They have been smearing and hurting conservatives and trafficking in this kind of hateful, unfunny stuff for the last year. But, on the show for an entire year, we've had montages this stuff from Chelsea Handler going after Melania, to -- I think the assassination jokes with Kathy Griffin and Johnny Depp. You've had Chris Matthew say horrible things. What they say on Morning Joe. The swear words on CNN. It's been despicable throughout the entire year. No one has ever condemned that. And here's the reasons why they condemned it this time. It was done in their room. It was done at their dinner by a comedian who they hired, and it was done to the person's face. All the other hateful stuff was on twitter. It was on someone else's show. They didn't have to take responsibility. The reason they had to condemn this comedian now was because it was a P.R. problem for them. They were only doing it for that reason and that reason alone.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Juan, to that point, do you think that the White House correspondents association was cowardly for distancing themselves? I don't think they should have distance themselves. They made the decision to have her there. They should have supported her, I think.

utterances.speaker: JUAN WILLIAMS, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Yeah. And I think they must be reacting to some backlash that they've received. And I think the backlash, to my mind, is someone who was there and who was sitting there -- there was no one walking out, by the way, was that you had Sarah Huckabee Sanders sitting on the stage. I believe she was two people removed from the lectern and she's sitting there, and even the TV cameras then enlarged the perspective so you could see Sanders reacting to Ms. Wolf. And the problem was that it just felt unfair to her. I thought -- you know, I saw Sarah Huckabee Sanders later and I held her hands and said I think you have a great sense of humor because in the moment you worry that she was going to burst into tears or stand up and walk out and there would be a whole deal about that, and that's not what the White House correspondents association want to their event. Where I disagree with you guys that she was hilarious, I think she was genius funny. I mean, you don't understand, she was picking on the press a lot. She was picking on Democrats. I mean, she said about the idea that Franken is gone. She said -- Ted Kennedy probably say, hey, I murdered a girl, that kind of thing.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That was a good joke.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know what? And I think -- when I sit here with all you guys, you talk about liberal intolerance for a variety of voices and speech. Well, gee, here's a variety -- here's a different perspective. And she went after and probably her most telling thing was, she said, you know, you guys in the press, you created this monster, and now you're all making -- your books, your podcasts, your TV shows making money and you -- but all you want to talk about is Trump and Russia. That was directly at the media.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah, that was good part.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And then, another good part was when she went after white women, and I've never heard anything like this. She said, hey, you think about what's going on, not only with Sarah Huckabee Sanders, but you think about Kellyanne Conway. You think about Ivanka. Everybody says, oh, women's issues are going to be at the forefront. She said you guys had disappointed white women, and she called them Uncle Toms.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: . in terms of white women. To me this was like -- everybody, let me tell you, where I was sitting, people were laughing.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, maybe you're at a different table because.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: . I watch the whole thing on C-Span, Juan. And she lost the crowd early and she bombed. And there's so much good material about the Trump White House from Acosta, to twitter, to the Russians, to Pelosi and Chuck Schumer. It's so easy to make a nice -- even clean joke. The majority of the stuff was very dirty. And I can handle dirty jokes. Everybody there can handle dirty jokes. I think it takes more talent to be clean. Almost everything was filthy.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You can be mean, but the jokes have to land.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Rally schedule?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: It's a tough thing. You know, I remember when Imus went after the Clinton's.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh, yeah.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: About extra marital affairs.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: . right with Mrs. Clinton.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I know.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: How about Larry Wilmore using the N-word in front of Obama.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, that -- See, I remember doing monos of all of these.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, you know.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Maybe this will be the last one.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: They don't need a comedian there. They can just use themselves.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: The president would be far funnier to be quite honest. He's great at the rallies. He's great when gets up and spoke at the Gridiron thing like Dana said. And that wasn't like mean spirited.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah. And they can all be their own punch lines. That's the fun part. OK. Should President Trump win a Nobel Prize for getting Kim Jong- un to make peace? The president of South Korea thinks so, next.

utterances.speaker: DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA
utterances.utterance: That's very nice, thank you. That's very nice. Nobel.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Chants of Nobel from a supportive crowd in Michigan. When President Obama left office he left President Trump with the world's biggest problem to solve, North Korea. This president didn't waste any time and took action. We've even witnessing remarkable results. Kim Jong- un is now signaling he wants to make peace, and lots of people are suggesting President Trump should win a Nobel Prize for that, including the leader of South Korea, Moon Jae-in. Lindsey Graham wants to see it happen, too.

utterances.speaker: SEN. LINDSEY GRAHAM (R), SOUTH CAROLINA
utterances.utterance: He can lead us to ending the Korean War after 70 years, and getting North Korea to give up their nuclear program in a verifiable way. He deserves the Nobel Peace Prize, and then some. I want to be there. Maybe the first time the Nobel Peace Prize was given and there was mass casualties because I think a lot of liberals would kill themselves if they did that.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, yes. And there's a lot of assumptions there. So, I think, there's a long way to get from A to B. But, yes, of course. If the Middle East peace -- that's next.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: North Korea -- I mean, if it happens, and it could be years from now. We might not even know for many, many years -- posterity might have to decide if that actually works out. Then, yes, of course he should definitely be on the list for a Nobel Prize. But I think that wanting a Nobel Prize to rub it in the face of your political opponents it's probably not the best way to go into a negotiation, and I don't think that's what President Trump is doing. I don't think he has grandiose ideas about getting the Nobel Prize. And I think that -- and also, you know, needling the Nobel Prize committee and say, oh, you'll never give it to him, you'll never give to him, it becomes like another thing that is just -- we have an amazing opportunity right now, mostly due to his strategic instincts to get this to the place where we have this moment. But we all know there's a catch. Kim Jong-un is getting to come to the table now as an equal, because he now has nuclear weapons, so their idea of denuclearization and our idea is very different. And so, let's just see what happens. And President Trump is very cautious when he talks about this. He should sound a hopeful note and then says, but we'll see. I don't know. Maybe I'll walk away. I don't care. Let's just see. And so, I think he's got the right attitude of people trying to push in for a Nobel Prize before they even, you know, basically, pour the water is a little premature.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Right. OK. So people criticized against President Obama, 12 days in.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: . Nobel Peace Prize, or was it like, whoa, OK.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Even Obama said OK.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: All right, Jesse?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, the president was asked about the Nobel Peace Prize and he said peace is the price. And that was a pretty slick answer.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Great line.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You've got to give him credit for that. If he does win, I think he should accept it during the military parade.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes. So, it's just a stark difference between President Obama and President Trump. When you look at what happened in the years under President Obama, you have the crisis in Syria, where he didn't enforce the red line. Chemical weapons were used on people. There was a migration crisis, and half a million people have died. North Korea nuked up. And then, ISIS took over third of Iraq. President Trump has come in and defeated the ISIS caliphate, brought the two people to the table on the North Korean peninsula, and launched a few tomahawk missiles against the Assad regime, so pretty impressive. And when you add on the top of the fact that the black unemployment is at the lowest levels, a lot of the things that you would necessarily give Obama credit for that he talked about happening are actually happening on President Trump's watch. I don't think liberals can handle it because it defeats their entire narrative about how evil and corrupt and ineffective President Trump is, but Trump will always be viewed as results driven. Obama was about hope, and he's about speeches, and he was about lofty ideals. But when you look at the actual results of this president compared to the last president, only in 16 months, I mean, the proof is in the pudding.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I see. Well, you know what I'm going to do now? I'm nominating you for the Trump cabinet, because I think that kind of thought.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I don't think I'd get through the vetting.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes, excellent.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You don't have to worry about that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: There's no extreme vetting.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes, Trump would love to hear from you. I'm telling you that. You know, I won't even have to go through line by line to say, that's a lot. But, I will say this, so it's the widow of a former president of South Korea who said, oh, you know, Moon Jae-in, who is the president of South Korea, now you should get a Nobel Prize for bringing folks to the table. Moon Jae-in very graciously said, oh, no, not me, President Trump. And why was that smart to quote Ms. Perino? It's smart because our president loves to be flattered. He loves to be.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Who doesn't?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I didn't say smart because of that. I've said smart because if you are thinking strategically on long term, you don't want to be the one taking the credit. You need the president to come to the table.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: . with your best interest in mind.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And you need the president to play along with you in order to achieve the end, and Moon Jae-in's end is peace on the Korean peninsula, and to try to, somehow, smooth out the difficulties that we all know had been interminable between North Korea, China, South Korea, Japan, and, of course, us, the USA. So, to me, this whole thing is about the people who are Trump supporters, so hungry for anything that would say their guy is great. He's doing great. He's doing fine. He's going to get a Nobel Peace Prize. It looks desperate to me.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, it doesn't -- I actually agree with you that people are hungry for that because they feel this is an injustice that this guy is doing a good job. You look at ISIS, you look at jobs, you look at North Korea, he's probably working on Iran right now.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Who said I'm going to pull out of Syria.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: And then he changed his mind.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Who's changing his mind.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Then we always see nobody is watching CNN.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: In the airports, Dana.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: OK. Well, this Stormy, like a three-minute encounter -- I don't know about that.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: The point is in the relative scheme of things of the world, we've got things going on in North Korea, South Korea. We have problems in Iran, Syria, all over the world. That's just foreign policy and national security. And guess what? I do want a president that's actually going to respond in real-time to what's happening in the theater and not to have a stagnant policy. Foreign policy must evolve and must adapt and pivot. It's also hand-in-hand with military policy and strategy, right? He has to be able to respond to it or he's not doing his job.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, I think other presidents have responded, but maybe not the way you wanted.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Trump is obsessed with Obama. He's always saying Obama did, Obama didn't.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Obama was never obsessed with.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I'm talking about.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: . George W. Bush.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I'm talking about.

utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: The caravan of asylum-seeking migrants is at America's southern border. And as you can see, our current wall in San Diego isn't doing much to stop them from entering. Many of the illegal immigrants are now camping out in Mexico after being turned away by the Trump administration. The president is reacting to this latest development by calling for funding for his big, beautiful border wall.

utterances.speaker: DONALD TRUMP (R), PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES
utterances.utterance: We are a nation of laws. We have to have borders. We don't have borders, we don't have a country. And I've been watching for weeks as the caravan came up. We have to have changes in Congress, and we have to have it quickly. We need a wall, No. 1. And you see that right now. You know, where they are, even though it's not a particularly good wall, and even though a small percentage can climb to the top, they have to be in extremely good shape. But a small percentage can climb that particular wall. We have a wall that's what's more difficult.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Vice President Pence was on the ground today in California, checking out the new border wall construction. Greg, you've said this a few times. The caravan was almost designed to help President Trump politically. What do you think?

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: It's a terrible visual image for amnesty and an amazing image for people who prefer process and enforced borders. But the most obvious question, if this is an asylum claim, why not just stop in Mexico? If you are truly desperate, right, you should be overjoyed to get out of your horrible country and get to Mexico. But no, you're saying, "Mexico is not enough for me. I need to get to the United States." That's insulting to Mexico, and it's kind of pushy. It's a bit -- you're cutting in line. I don't -- Americans don't like it when you cut in line. And when you look at the groups, there's a lot of young, able-bodied men showing up. And you think, "These are not refugees." This is a symbolic political gesture that is backfiring. When you see that, it's backfiring. All it does is just prove that we need law and order; we need process.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Look at that visual right there. I mean, you're right. It's made to order. Anybody that sees this in this country sees how easy it is to breach our southern border, Kimberly. Look at that. And the minute they step foot on American soil, they're entitled to a process where then they can go in front of a judge and claim that they're scared to return to Honduras.

utterances.speaker: KIMBERLY GUILFOYLE, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Yes, that's the problem, you know. So everybody but -- when people are desperate and they're trying to flee their countries, they'll do just about anything for themselves and for their family. When you have that kind of sense of desperation: where will I work tomorrow? How will I feed my children? So that's why you have mothers, pregnant mothers even going -- coming over here. and they are, like, "Listen, I hear that if I come over and I can give birth in the United States, then my child can stay there and, hopefully, then the rest of the family can come." That is their business plan. That is the business plan. And of course this is a country founded on immigrants, wonderful people from all over the world. So we want to have open arms and be welcoming, but we want to do it with an eye towards public safety and national security and securing the border, because it makes for a safer situation for everyone and for a lawful process that should be followed and abided by. So the president is fulfilling his campaign promises. We understand his reasoning, and then it's also important, if you're going to try to work on it, to make it more of a -- you know, a cooperative understanding. What's going on here, they've got to come into the laws, to enjoy the benefit of being in this country, but follow the law first before you get in.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right. So you want to be compassionate but also fair --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- and tough, Juan. So the president wants --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: People waiting in line.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right. He wants merit-based immigration, too. And that's important when you see these images.

utterances.speaker: JUAN WILLIAMS, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Well, this is not about merit-based.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: This is about asylum. And remember, Greg, that in fact this caravan, which is an annual event, I think --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- for the last five years or so. Most of the people did stop in Mexico. You have about 50 people who were trying to get in here, and what they want to do is to force the United States to give them an asylum hearing.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And they believe that, based on the evidence of not only political instability but actual violence, oftentimes perpetrated by gangs and the like, that they have a case to be made. And that's why you have American lawyers on the other side of the fence, giving them counseling about what to say, how to handle the asylum situation. But I agree with you guys. I think this is tailor-made for President Trump and people who are anti-immigrant to say, "Hey, the border --"

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Anti-illegal immigrant.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, no, because remember, Trump's proposal --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Not anti-immigrant.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- was to cut legal immigration to the United States.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Because he wants merit-based, not the lottery.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, no. Excuse me. He didn't -- it didn't matter. Merit or not merit, he wanted to cut legal immigration.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: As a result of merit-based.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, no, no. He just wants to cut every -- he even wants to cut people who are qualified for legal merit-based immigration. But I just say --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Can we get Dana in real quick? Let me get Dana. So the president also says he wants to get more funding for the wall next time in the fall, wants to shut the government down if he doesn't get it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes. Yes, so September 28, it's all setting up for a really big midterm election campaign issue. I think that this video is an in-kind contribution to President Trump. And he might have to check out what those contribution limits are down there. I do think that the president could be in a position now. When -- these people will not all get in. They'll have to go back. But one thing that he could do -- he's on, like, a foreign policy roll right now. And he's had some really good meetings with world leaders. And these people in El Salvador, Nicaragua, Costa Rica, et cetera, that have these problems. Just like we've been saying about Syria. If you help solve the problem at its source --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: -- and if the issue is law and order, if the president can figure out a way to help them with their law and order problem, people won't want to leave home.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, we definitely need to focus on Central America a little bit more. All right. Ahead, a merry-go-round of excuses from MSNBC host Joy Reid. Her pals in the liberal media, of course, rushing to her defense. The hypocrisy up next.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Welcome back. MSNBC's Joy Reid is continuing to feel the heat over controversial blog posts. The anchor's lawyer saying last week that the FBI was investigating potential hacking. But now Reid says there's no proof.

utterances.speaker: JOY REID, MSNBC
utterances.utterance: I genuinely do not believe I wrote those hateful things, because they are completely alien to me. But I can definitely understand, based on things I have tweeted and have written in the past, why some people don't believe me. I have not been exempt from being dumb or cruel or hurtful to the very people I want to advocate for. I own that. I get it. And for that, I am truly, truly sorry.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, this is interesting, because even now that she says that she hired, the cybersecurity folks, couldn't find any evidence that there was manipulation, she says she still doesn't believe she wrote some of it. But some of the stuff that she does say she wrote, Jesse, it was pretty awful in terms of going after the gay community.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It wasn't great. It was offensive. But you know, I'd rather listen to the news from someone that's offensive than someone who's a liar. She thinks her audience are idiots. I mean, come on. We're not stupid. We get that you wrote these things, and we get that you're lying about that. I was reading Axios over the weekend, Dana, and they made a very good point about how Brian Williams was treated. Remember, he misremembered or wasn't completely honest about a war story. He was not fired. He was then kind of demoted to MSNBC. So they're not going to treat Brian Williams any -- the same as Joy Reid. Both of them lied or misremembered, and they're both probably going to stay.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, Dana, is it worse than -- I mean, one of the arguments would be MSNBC says if you're homophobic, that's a firable offense, but if you sort of tell -- didn't understand, maybe you lied. I don't know.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Did you lie about your homophobia?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, I would -- I would certainly defend her right to say anything and also to change her opinion and to talk about it. I do -- I did hesitate last week, because I thought I don't understand this whole hacking thing. And then it sounds like, "Oh, we can't find proof yet." And it -- there is a real double standard with people being run out of town or publications based on their prior writings. And one great example, just two weeks ago Kevin Williamson, a fantastic writer from National Review, a conservative, gets hired by the Atlantic. I was so excited. I was like, "Oh, I'm going to re-subscribe to The Atlantic." So I did. He starts -- he wrote one piece for them. It was a fantastic piece. But they looked back and they say, "Oh, he wants to basically have -- women who have abortions should be hanged." They don't give him a chance to explain his position. He actually was willing to explain it all. He didn't say, "I don't actually think I wrote that. I'm pretty sure that wasn't me." He was willing to own it and to explain his position, which actually does make sense to me when you listen to it in full. So there is a lot of double standards going around here.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So Kimberly, she did lose -- or at least have her column at The Daily Beast suspended. And I think she's under tremendous pressure at the moment. What do you think?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Well, I mean, she made the comments, right? So she had to come out and she had to apologize. Hopefully, she uses this as a, you know, teachable moment for herself to try to move forward, to understand that that kind of, you know, bigotry should not be tolerated. She's somebody that has, you know, spoken out on behalf of women's rights. She's quick to criticize other people, but now she's had to, you know, look in the mirror and say, "Wait a second. Did I make these comments? Were they offensive?" And address, you know, the public to say, "Here's where I am." So let's see where she goes, you know, going forward. There's already been some repercussions from it, right? So hopefully, she's going to learn. She's going to think about what she's saying and what she's doing and how she's treating other people.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And Greg, you said, you know, Americans do have evolving opinions on gay rights.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. And you know what? I am pro stupid amnesty. Everyone has said stupid things. We all have. And I mean, we talked about this, how Kanye said awful things about George Bush. Donald Trump has said awful things that he probably regrets if he doesn't -- if he's already forgotten. Maybe not. But I guess my problem is I don't think the -- I don't think the people supporting Joy Reid, like Media Matters, will reserve the same kind of compassion for us. They will come for us with the knives out. Anytime we screw up, they want our jobs.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Double standard.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They do the boycotts. I get the impulse at MSNBC to circle the wagon, but I hope, if you're watching, that this compromises your future attempts to demonize adversaries over a target. When you -- when one of us says something that is stupid, you should say, "You know what? That guy defended Joy Reid, and he was right."

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes. And we're going to say, "I don't remember saying that."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Well-rehearsed, Greg and Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: All right, a behind-the-scenes look at one of the hottest dinners in Nashville. Guess why? Dana and Jesse were waiting on the tables. Don't miss it. Straight ahead.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Last week, Jesse and I had the honor of attending the waiting for 17th annual Waiting for Wishes Dinner in Nashville to help raise money for some very special charities. At this dinner, we waited the tables, and it was an amazing night. Jesse, we haven't seen this yet.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Let's welcome Dana Perino. Jesse Watters.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I don't know how Jesse Watters got invited, though. Do you want to tell us anything about that?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: I don't know either. It was a complete surprise to me, too.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You guys want a picture with the real (UNINTELLIGIBLE). Here we go.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Wait, this is my world! He's like my kid brother. I've got to take him along with me everywhere. I did wait tables years ago. So we'll figure this out. I'm not even sure what I'm doing. But we'll make it work.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I need brown bread. They told me that someone needs brown bread. Three plates!

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Jesse, are you working?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I'm working. I'm taking pictures here.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Are you hardly working?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I need brown bread for a table. More of that brown bread. Where do I get that? It's in the kitchen. Can I butter your roll?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Actually, if you could do that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I'm going to butter your roll. Do you like a lot of butter or a little butter?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: A lot. A lot.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Want me to slather it on? Let me sign something. You probably just want the NFL players to sign it. Am I going to ruin it?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: How much is Jasper worth?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You better be putting money in for me. Right?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And you can vote for me. You know how to do that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Steak knives for everybody. Twenty dollars a knife. I'm going to dig in.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Go ahead.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: We're friends, right?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What do you want, medium rare? That's good.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Is that good?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: This is Bailey. Make him famous.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I like the pocket square. That's sharp. Can I give you a little secret? Dress for the job you want, not for the job you have.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I've got to take a plate back.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: You're just doing it for the camera. We know.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Are you eating that?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I'm actually working. This is not my place. I just sat down.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: You worked the whole night.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: We've got Jesse Watters and Dana Perino. I mean, obviously --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Jesse, that made us look like we were the only celebrities there.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I know. There was a lot bigger celebrities.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Much bigger celebrities. It was a really amazing --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You're a good waitress. You had plates going up your arm.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes, that's how I got through college.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Wow.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: And she was a DJ. She's recession proof.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I mean, I worked a lot. But it was a really wonderful event. What did you think about meeting Kevin Carter?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He was great. And that young man who I give a tip about the pocket square, he was the ambassador. He's a young kid. And we raised a lot of money for the Make-a-Wish Foundation, so it was worthwhile. Maybe Kimberly can come next year and wait some tables, as well. Juan, I'm not so sure. Greg is probably busy.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I'm very good at dishes, too.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Oh, but you know what they have? They needed bartenders.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I would be a great bartender.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Chris Collinsworth bartended the entire thing. I think that was his way of getting out of waiting tables.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Also, Tito Ortiz was there. And that was a big deal, right?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He gave me a tip on how to fight. He said, "If you're ever in a fight, Watters, punch them in the nose."

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: He's right.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Because it stuns them and then their eyes water, and they'll blink.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Because like, he can punch. And you could...

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I can take a punch. I've got a big chain.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I've never been to an event like that before where you have all sorts of different people. And the patrons, they pay to come to the dinner, but then they have to pay extra for all sorts of other things. And then there's the live auction.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's right. And someone won a tour of FOX News, and they're going to watch "The Five" show, as well.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Cool.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: What did they pay for that?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I'm not going to tell.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I know. Do you know?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I know, but I think you took a cut of that, didn't you, Dana?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: No, I didn't take a cut. Oh, my gosh. But it was a lot. And of course, it's going to be worth it. All right. Thanks for inviting us. "One More Thing" is up next.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: "One More Thing." Well, you probably didn't know this, but I'm quite the entrepreneur. I spend my weekends trying to invent new products. And I think I came across something that I think is going to be very big.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Let's see.

utterances.speaker: KAT TIMPF, FOX NEWS
utterances.utterance: Sometimes I need the hard news of the day. But other times I just want to cuddle. Why can't I have both?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
